author: The Journal Of Turkish Weekly
title: India clears defense deals worth $4.7 billion
text:
(MENAFN - The Journal Of Turkish Weekly) India's defense ministry on Tuesday approved defense deals worth 4.7 billion, Indian media reported. 

A council headed by Defense Minister Manohar Parrikar cleared the long-pending projects to modernize the country's ageing defense equipment according to local news channel NDTV on Wednesday. 

Among the purchases will be four spy planes from Boeing and more than 400 anti-aircraft guns worth 2.67 billion, to replace existing Swedish and Russian-made guns that are more than 40 years old. 

The new anti-aircraft guns will be manufactured in India as part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "Make in India" drive to make the country a manufacturing hub and create local employment.

Major Indian companies like larsen & Toubro, Tata, Bharat Electronics and Bharat Forge have reportedly shown interest in manufacturing defense equipment locally after a transfer of technology from abroad and have been allowed to have a 49 percent stake in defense joint-ventures.

India under Modi has been keen to do away with its tag as the world's largest importer of arms.

India has gradually modernized its defense equipment recently; in April, Modi sealed a deal with France to buy 36 Rafale fighter jets.

In 2009, India had signed a deal with Boeing to purchase eight P-81 patrol aircrafts; out of which seven have already been delivered.
